title: Drag-and-Drop Timeline
credits: Created by the National Museum of the American Indian. Designed and developed by Interactive Mechanics.

Moments.title: Time Immemorial
Moments.description: Traditional belief holds that the Creator placed Native peoples on Earth; in return for their taking care of Earth and its resources, the Creator would provide all that they would need to thrive, for generations to come.
Moments.caption: Native peoples engineered a variety of tools and techniques to harvest salmon. The hook-and-line method reflects the sustainable practice of taking enough fish for a family or community while leaving healthy, sustainable amounts of fish to spawn and migrate.
Moments.credit: Quileute iron salmon hook, ca.1890. NMAI 057591
Moments.excerpt: Traditional belief holds that the Creator placed Native peoples on Earth to care and protect for its resources.

Moments.title: Palmer and Stevens Treaties
Moments.description: Treaties between Pacific Northwest Native Nations and the emerging U.S. government are rapidly negotiated (1854–1856) to allow for American settlement of Indian lands.
Moments.caption: The Treaty of Medicine Creek, like others negotiated in the Pacific Northwest in the mid-1850s, guarantees the right to harvest fish, game, and other foods in “usual and accustomed” grounds located outside reservation boundaries.
Moments.excerpt: Treaties between Pacific Northwest Native Nations and the emerging U.S. government are rapidly negotiated (1854–1856).

Moments.title: U.S. v Winnans
Moments.description: Supreme Court holds that treaty Indians reserved the right to fish at “usual and accustomed” places and that treaties are to be interpreted the way Indians had understood them. “And all treaties made, or which shall be made under the authority of the United States shall be the Supreme Law of the Land and the judges in every state shall be bound thereby” - Article VI, U.S. Constitution
Moments.excerpt: Supreme Court holds that treaty Indians reserved the right to fish at “usual and accustomed” places.

Moments.title: “Fish Ins” begin
Moments.description: In an effort to defend their treaty rights, Indian Peoples along the Puget Sound begin to stage protests called fish-ins.
Moments.caption: Billy Frank, Jr. fishing the Nisqually River in 1973 in an act of civil disobedience.
Moments.credit: Photograph by Tom Thompson, courtesy of  NWIFC
Moments.excerpt: In an effort to defend their treaty rights, Native communities stage protests called fish-ins

Moments.title: U.S. Justice Department files a lawsuit on behalf of treaty tribes
Moments.description: Suit lands in hands of U.S. district court judge George H. Boldt; court proceedings last three years. “There was a real tradition, in the Pacific Northwest of tribal people going to the courts. That the courts were the only real remedy that they were going to find.” - John Platt, NMAI Interview, August 2016
Moments.excerpt: “There was a real tradition, in the Pacific Northwest of tribal people going to the courts. That the courts were the only real remedy that they were going to find.” - John Platt, NMAI Interview, August 2016

Moments.title: Boldt Decision
Moments.description: Landmark decision in favor of Native Nations; court affirms that tribal fishing rights are “protected under the supreme law of the land” and state laws do not trump treaty guarantees. Treaty tribes are entitled to “take an equal share of the salmon harvest”—fifty percent.
Moments.caption: Major opponents to treaty fishing rights were hunting and fishing organizations, not just the state of Washington's fisheries and game departments.
Moments.credit: Don Hannula, “Sportsmen protest decision,” Seattle Times, March 5, 1974
Moments.excerpt: Landmark decision in favor of Native Nations; court affirms that tribal fishing rights are “protected under the supreme law of the land”

Moments.title: Boldt Appeal
Moments.description: U.S. court of appeals affirms Judge Boldt’s holding and rules that states cannot pass laws that infringe on treaty protected rights.
Moments.caption: Hatred and outrage were expressed in a variety of ways and in a variety of places. The Boldt effigy was hung outside the federal courthouse where Judge Boldt presided.
Moments.credit: Photograph by staff photographer Matt McVay, Seattle Times, September 11, 1977
Moments.excerpt: U.S. court of appeals affirms Judge Boldt’s holding

Moments.title: CRITFC created; NWIFC created
Moments.description: Native Nations join forces to create fishing commissions to ensure treaty fishing rights are resolved in keeping with the restoration of tribal fisheries.
Moments.caption: Member nations of fishing commissions like the CRITFC and NWIFC coordinate with state and federal agencies to ensure fair harvesting practices between tribal and nontribal fishers.
Moments.credit: Seal of the Northwest Fisheries Commission, Seal of the Columbia Inter-Tribal Fish Commission
Moments.excerpt: Native Nations join forces to create fishing commissions

Moments.title: Washington State submits appeal to U.S. Supreme Court
Moments.description: Supreme Court denies Washington state’s petition for certiorari (hear the case); Boldt Decision remains in effect. “What Judge Boldt did and what the Supreme Court did was not give rights in those cases, they affirmed them. In other words, they said those rights are there, we recognize them.” - Elizabeth Furse (Former Congresswoman), NMAI Interview August 2016
Moments.excerpt: Supreme Court denies Washington state’s petition for certiorari (hear the case); Boldt Decision remains in effect

Moments.title: U.S./Canada Pacific Salmon Treaty
Moments.description: Treaty adds tribal representation to the international decision-making body along with other government fish managers. “The Pacific Salmon Treaty covers fisheries occuring across more than a thousand miles of coastline, ranging from central Oregon through southeast Alaska. These fisheries are the cornerstone of many coastal communities, providing jobs for fishermen and supporting centuries old traditions of First Nations and Indian Tribes” Quoted from Pacific Salmon Treaty and Commission Fact Sheet http://www.westcoast.fisheries.noaa.gov/publications/fishery_management/salmon_steelhead/pacific_salmon_treaty_fact_sheet_022315.pdf
Moments.excerpt: Treaty adds tribal representation to the international decision-making body along with other government fish managers.

Moments.title: Endangered Species Act
Moments.description: Several salmon runs from the Snake River, the Columbia’s largest tributary were listed under the Endangered Species Act.
Moments.excerpt: Several salmon runs from the Snake River, the Columbia’s largest tributary were listed under the Endangered Species Act.

Moments.title: Rafeedie Ruling
Moments.description: Federal District Judge Edward Rafeedie rules that treaties’ “in common” language means the tribes reserved harvest rights to half of all shellfish from all of the usual and accustomed places.
Moments.excerpt: Federal court rules that “in common” language applies to shellfish harvest rights

Moments.title: “Boldt 40”
Moments.description: The 40th anniversary of the Boldt Decision.  Sponsored by the NWIFC and Salmon Defense Fund, treaty tribes and non-Indian allies celebrate successes and confront ongoing challenges to restore salmon in the Pacific Northwest.
Moments.caption: Twelve speakers were honored with Pendleton blankets for participating in panel discussions at Boldt 40, February 5 at the Squaxin Island Tribe’s Skookum Event Center. Three of them, from left, are Alan Stay, attorney for the Muckleshoot Tribe; Bill Wilkerson, former director of the state Department of Fish and Wildlife; and Fawn Sharp, president of the Quinault Nation. The day commemorated the 40th anniversary of the U.S. District Court decision in U.S. vs. Washington
Moments.credit: Photograph and caption by Richard Walker, credited to Indian Country Today.
Moments.excerpt: The 40th anniversary of the Boldt Decision
